resources.string: "Syllables "TI–DO." Reference: Theme from "Jaws." Fun Fact: Smallest interval in major scale."
"Syllables “DO–RE.” Reference: "Happy BIRTHday." Fun Fact: Two m2nds equal one M2."
"Syllables "MI–SOL." References: "This Old Man," "Hey Jude," "FROSTY the Snowman." Fun Fact: Top part of the major triad (DO–MI–SOL)."
"Syllables “DO-MI.” References: “Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony,” “Summertime.” Fun Fact: Bottom part of the major triad."
"Syllables “DO-FA.” References: “Here Comes the Bride,” “Oh Christmas Tree.” Fun Fact: Only one m2nd higher than M3rd."

"Syllables "DO–FI" (as in "fee"). References: "Maria" from West Side Story, "The Simpsons" Theme. Fun Fact: FI is one m2nd higher than FA and typically resolves to SOL (one m2nd above FI). Also called a tritone."
"Syllables “DO–SOL.” Reference: "Twinkle, Twinkle…" Fun Fact: First and third notes of the major triad (DO–MI–SOL)."
"Syllables “DO–LE” (as in “lay”). References: “The Entertainer,” Lady Gaga “Bad Romance” (RA RA…), Usher “Yeah” (Synth). Fun Fact: Only one m2nd higher than P5 and often resolves down to SOL."
"Syllables “DO–LA.” References: The NB part of “NBC” Theme, “DASHING through the snow…” Fun Fact: One M2nd higher than the P5."
"Syllables "DO–TE" (as in "tay"). Reference: “THERE'S A…place for us” from West Side Story. Fun Fact: TE creates a dissonant interval that often revolves down by m2nd to LA."

"Syllables “DO–TI.” Reference: In the film, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, from the song "Pure Imagination": "…in A WORLD of pure imagination." Fun Fact: The M7th usually resolves by m2nd to the P8 above."
"Syllables “DO–DO.” Reference: “SOMEWHERE over the rainbow” from The Wizard of Oz. Fun Fact: In "The Star-Spangled Banner," the following words are a separated by an octave: SAY and SEE."
Please select one of the answers!
Replay limit reached - please submit answer!

"Welcome fellow musicians and music lovers! To help out in developing a finely-tuned aural awareness of intervals, this tutor space will provide you with some helpful strategies. We can define an interval as how far apart two notes are from each other. With that in mind, here are some terms and concepts to consider.
1. Some common abbreviations of the intervals are the following:
M = major m = minor o = diminished + = augmented P = perfect
2. One of the larger skills this app aims to develop is your ability to audiate— or hear these intervals in your head without any aural cues. When you are in Flash Card Mode, test yourself to see if you can sing each interval before hearing each one. The great tools to help you are the “solfeggio” syllables. For a major scale, the syllables are the following: DO–RE–MI–FA–SOL–LA–TI–DO. If you can sing the major scale, then you have all of the intervals you need to learn for this app (of course, some intervals—like the P12—are “compound” intervals, and encompass a wider interval space than the typical octave range of the scale). Always check your singing attempt in Flash Card Mode with the recording or with your instrument. If your music-reading ability is less than ideal, just know that the second note’s height is related to the higher- numbered intervals.
3. Once you begin making associations with the intervals you hear in Flash Card Mode, and after you have tested your memory of the sound and distance of each interval, you are ready for aural tests in Quiz Mode. Again, the best way to memorize the intervals is to connect them to something you have already heard (e.g., from a favorite song). If the interval is brand new, then you can use the scale for reference (and memorize the syllables).
4. Think of the two notes as part of a melody or as an outline of a familiar harmony. Some harmonies are more stable than others. Consonant intervals (major/minor 3rds/6ths and perfects 4ths/5ths) are more stable than dissonant intervals (augmented/ diminished intervals and major/minor 2nds/7ths); and dissonant intervals carry resolution implications. So in the case of dissonance, it’s helpful to ask yourself: What is the consonant resolution of this interval?
"

"Thank you for using this app! Here are the folks responsible: Nathan Foxley, Box Metaphor Studios founder, lead programmer and master's in music theory holder.
James Lloyd: Designer, illustrator, and all around good guy.
Steve Mathews: Music theory expert and tester.
Our hired hand and freelancer Davor Slamnig was crutial to the programming process.
Email questions and bug issues to support@boxmetaphorstudios.com."

"Welcome to the Aural Skills Trainer: Intervals app! On the home page, you'll find options to check out flash cards, do a quiz and configure options. We recommend checking out the "Tutor" mode in the options menu to help you get started, especially if you're new to thinking about intervals. Thank you for downloading this app and wanting to learn more about music!
